answers.answer: Hi,Bacteria are subjectively quantified in urine and may be observed as few, moderate and many. These may be insignificant contaminants such as  small amorphous crystals, cellular debris, and small fat droplets. Or it may be associated with pathogens. Factors such as presence of other symptoms, the method of urine collection, the number and types of bacteria, the presence of leukocytes in urine, the length of urine storage, the container, and any underlying disease are important considerations in evaluation of the urine result.  Presence of pyuria  or white blood cells usually signifies urinary tract infection (UTI).  The risk factors for  UTI  include predisposition for bladder infections  in families; presence of diabetes, being uncircumcised,  catheter use, decreased fluid intake, holding the urine for too long, or having a large prostate  and not necessarily through public toilet or toilet water. Hope this helps. Take care and do keep us posted.

question: i was tested for lymes and  my urine showed bacteria,i have no symptoms of bladder trouble but do have flu like or lymes  disease, I am married for a couple years and i am positive my wife and have never cheated so how did i get bacteria in my urine? the other thing is gross but we have a few sexually active boys(4) that sometimes dont flush the toilet and on a couple of occasions ive sat on it in the dark and have had the tip of my penis fall in the dirty water,and in a public toilet once or twice.Is it possible thats were the bacterium came from or could we have been passing it back and forth and not know about it? thanks.
title: bacteria in urine
